kwd-group.kwd: Advanced Practice Registered Nurse Consensus Model

body.p: The article “Nursing Science and Public Health: Contributions to the Discipline of Nursing” (Kulbok & Ervin, 2012) provided an in-depth analysis of the emerging issues related to the endorsement of the consensus model for advanced practice registered nurse (APRN) regulation by the APRN Consensus Workgroup and the National Council of State Boards of Nursing (NCSBN). The authors criticized the consensus model for APRN regulation as a medically-based regulatory model that disenfranchises public health nursing (PHN) from advanced practice nursing with its definition. More important, this model is discordant to the principles and values central to PHN. I have found these critiques very insightful, practical, and reflecting clearly the controversies related to this model.

As a master’s-prepared registered nurse practicing at community level in public health for the past 10 years, I, like many nurses in the PHN specialty, have the same question about my professional identity and the meanings of my practice. Apparently the APRN consensus model is not the answer. Chinn and Kramer said that “professional identity that evolves from distinct disciplinary knowledge provides a basis from which nurses can create certain aspects of their practice” (p. 23). Advanced practice PHN is distinctive by its focus on health promotion and disease prevention of communities and populations. I agree with the authors that PHN needs to adopt a framework, which can define the scope of practice, maintain the integrity of PHN principles, and address the uniqueness of PHN as a specialized branch of nursing discipline.

The integrated knowledge development framework for PHN proposed by the authors emphasized knowledge development as key to drive education, research, and practice. For practice, I believe PHN still needs to acquire an operational framework to define its scope of practice and the meanings and purposes of the profession. The three PHN models that the authors identified are good examples of advanced PHN practice (Brooten et al., 2002; Eckenrode et al., 2010; Naylor et al., 1999).

When the APRN Consensus Workgroup and NCSBN endorsed the APRN consensus model, they aimed to provide uniformity of advanced nursing practice inside the nursing discipline. However, this regulatory model will lead to divergence among various nursing specialties. I thank the authors for bringing these issues to the attention of nurses and suggesting the need for further discussions.
